previewParagraphs: With PSV Eindhoven sitting comfortably at the top of the Eredivisie and Utrecht searching for a way to bounce back from a tough run, all eyes will be on Stadion Galgenwaard as these teams face off on December 21, 2025.
Both teams have plenty to play for, but the visitors arrive with some impressive recent statistics, while Utrecht look for a much-needed spark to turn their fortunes around.

Looking at recent encounters, Utrecht have found it challenging to assert themselves when PSV Eindhoven are in town. In their last five home fixtures against the league leaders, they have drawn three and lost two, without a single victory. This underlines the difficulties Utrecht have faced in turning home advantage into positive results against the Eindhoven side.

Examining Utrecht’s current form raises further concerns. Across their last six matches in all competitions, Utrecht haven’t tasted victory, registering four draws and two losses. They have averaged 1.17 goals scored while conceding 1.5 per game in the stretch, and their offensive output—averaging only 4.33 shots on target from 12 attempts per match—highlights a lack of cutting edge in the final third.

The story at home offers slight improvements with one win, one draw, and one loss in their last three matches at Stadion Galgenwaard. However, their average possession drops to just 37%, and the attack still finds it hard to create high-quality chances.

The bigger trends don’t paint a better picture: Utrecht have been winless in 11 of their last 13 in all competitions, and 100% winless in their last six. Yet, digging deeper, the team has shown some resilience at home, standing undefeated in 80% of their last 20 home games across all competitions, and 11 of their last 12 Eredivisie home fixtures. Their ability to avoid defeat, especially in draws, is highlighted by a 50% draw rate in their last 10 league games.

PSV Eindhoven, under Peter Bosz, bring astonishing away records. They have won 83% of their last 12 matches in all competitions, and are undefeated in 80% of their last 40. Their attack is particularly sharp, with an average of 2.67 goals per game in the last six. PSV’s overall away numbers impress: undefeated in 18 of their last 20, with a 63% away win rate, and boasting 3 clean sheets in their previous 7 on the road.

In Eredivisie action, PSV have shone with 29 wins in their last 40 league matches and a stunning +30 goal difference. The team consistently creates danger, averaging more than 7.6 shots on goal and over 63% possession in their league matches, reflecting a dominant style of play.

On an individual level, Utrecht must cope without four sidelined players including Victo Jensen, Niklas Vesterlund, Matisse Didden, and Emirhan Demircan. This will require some reshuffling, particularly in defense and midfield.
Given the recurring formations and considering available players, the most probable Utrecht starting eleven is likely to line up in a 4-2-3-1:
previewText:
With PSV Eindhoven sitting comfortably at the top of the Eredivisie and Utrecht searching for a way to bounce back from a tough run, all eyes will be on Stadion Galgenwaard as these teams face off on December 21, 2025.

Both teams have plenty to play for, but the visitors arrive with some impressive recent statistics, while Utrecht look for a much-needed spark to turn their fortunes around.

Their ability to avoid defeat, especially in draws, is highlighted by a 50% draw rate in their last 10 league games.

PSV Eindhoven, under Peter Bosz, bring astonishing away records. They have won 83% of their last 12 matches in all competitions, and are undefeated in 80% of their last 40. Their attack is particularly sharp, with an average of 2.67 goals per game in the last six. PSV’s overall away numbers impress: undefeated in 18 of their last 20, with a 63% away win rate, and boasting 3 clean sheets in their previous 7 on the road.

In Eredivisie action, PSV have shone with 29 wins in their last 40 league matches and a stunning +30 goal difference. The team consistently creates danger, averaging more than 7.6 shots on goal and over 63% possession in their league matches, reflecting a dominant style of play.

On an individual level, Utrecht must cope without four sidelined players including Victo Jensen, Niklas Vesterlund, Matisse Didden, and Emirhan Demircan. This will require some reshuffling, particularly in defense and midfield.

Given the recurring formations and considering available players, the most probable Utrecht starting eleven is likely to line up in a 4-2-3-1:
originalTitle: PSV Eindhoven Aim to Extend Dominance at Stadion Galgenwaard Against Struggling Utrecht
Feyenoord vs Twente: Battle of Streaks Set for Stadio Feijenoord

previewParagraphs: The Serie A encounter between Sassuolo and Torino at the MAPEI Stadium finds both teams searching for form, but the numbers suggest a potential edge for the hosts. With both sides coming off inconsistent stretches, this matchup will hinge on who adapts best to their recent challenges.

The most recent clash between these two teams finished in a 1-1 draw, a match that highlighted Torino’s command of possession but lacked a decisive killer instinct in the final third. Played on February 10, 2024, Sassuolo struck early through Andrea Pinamonti in the 5th minute, only for Duván Zapata to restore parity four minutes later for Torino. The visitors enjoyed 59% of possession and outshot Sassuolo 13 to 11, but Sassuolo created more dangerous situations, with 46 dangerous attacks to Torino’s 38. Both sides had their share of efforts on goal, but neither could break down the rival’s defense after the frantic opening.
These details illustrate a fairly balanced fixture, with Torino’s ball retention offset by Sassuolo’s sharpness in attacking phases, particularly in home conditions.

Sassuolo’s last six matches have been varied, posting two wins, two draws, and two losses. Importantly, they have averaged 1.83 goals per match while conceding 1.5, suggesting both effectiveness in attack and lingering fragilities at the back.

At home, their record steadies somewhat, with one win, one draw, and one loss in their last three at the MAPEI Stadium. Notably, their shot production soars at home to an average of 15.67 total shots and over five efforts on target per match, driven by an average possession of 54.67% over these fixtures.

Torino, on the other hand, are laboring through a difficult sequence, with only one win from their last six, alongside three losses. Their scoring rate in this span is just 1.17 goals per game, while conceding two, exposing defensive vulnerabilities. Away from home, Torino have failed to win any of their last three, netting only 0.33 goals on average and conceding 0.67, while their ball possession slips further, to 36%.

Sassuolo sit 9th in Serie A with six wins, three draws, and six losses across 15 matches, yielding a positive goal difference of +2 (21 scored, 19 conceded). Their average of 1.4 goals per game marks them as one of the more consistent mid-table attacks, even as defensive issues persist.

Torino’s challenges are clearer: currently 13th in the standings with just four victories in 15, accompanied by five draws and six defeats. Their defense has struggled, allowing 26 goals (1.73 per match), and a -11 goal difference underlines the margin of their setbacks.

Sassuolo have proven difficult to beat at home, going undefeated in 20 of their last 25 home matches in all competitions. They also have a propensity to control proceedings with an average home ball possession near 52%, and have won by two or more goals in 39% of their last 28 MAPEI fixtures.

Torino’s away struggles stand out: they are winless in 11 of their last 12 away encounters. While their defense records clean sheets in 43% of their last 7 away games, over their last 14 away matches, losses have occurred in half, and offensive productivity remains low.

originalTitle: Sassuolo Look to Assert Home Strength Against Torino Amid Mixed Runs
